topics.title: Cold open: why strategy is hard
topics.summary: Roger argues most people struggle with strategy because business schools and companies don’t train it well, and because strategy is both intellectually integrative and emotionally intimidating.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Roger Martin and previews the episode’s focus: a tactical framework for crafting strategy and building strategic thinking skills.

topics.title: Strategy isn’t just for executives
topics.summary: They discuss why strategy should be practiced by people deep in the org, using Procter & Gamble as an example of training brand managers to make consequential strategic choices.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Webflow and WorkOS.

topics.title: Why people are bad at strategy
topics.summary: Roger breaks down the core difficulties: strategy requires integrated choices, forces tradeoffs, and is poorly taught due to academic incentives and consulting industry shifts away from strategy work.

topics.title: Business school strategy and the RBV critique
topics.summary: Roger critiques the resource-based view of the firm as an unhelpful academic backlash to Porter, arguing it fails to guide real resource investment decisions and dominates hiring/teaching.

topics.title: Where Helmer and Rumelt fit in
topics.summary: Roger positions Hamilton Helmer as a practical strategist with a useful “how to win” categorization, and criticizes Rumelt’s hypercompetition framing and weak grounding in business reality.

topics.title: Defining strategy: choices that compel customers
topics.summary: Roger defines strategy as an integrated set of choices that compels desired customer action, emphasizing companies control decisions but not customers—strategy bridges that gap.

topics.title: The strategy choice cascade: five questions
topics.summary: Roger explains the five-question cascade (winning aspiration, where to play, how to win, capabilities, management systems) and how it emerged from trying to operationalize Porter-style outputs.

topics.title: Playing to win vs playing to play
topics.summary: They discuss how customer behavior reveals whether you’re truly winning, and Roger argues sustainable advantage requires either differentiation or low cost—otherwise competitors can “bully” you.

topics.title: Differentiation needs defensible capabilities
topics.summary: Roger explains that being “better” isn’t enough unless competitors can’t or won’t replicate it, using Amazon vs Walmart and Tesla vs OEMs to illustrate inertia and head starts as advantage drivers.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Cycle, an AI-powered product feedback platform.

topics.title: Moats, replication barriers, and Westlaw example
topics.summary: They connect defensible advantage to “moats” (Buffett), discuss Helmer’s categorization, and Roger illustrates a hard-to-copy capability stack via Westlaw’s lawyer-built legal search system.

topics.title: Applying the cascade to FigJam
topics.summary: They walk through how FigJam might define aspiration and where-to-play choices (customers, channels, product scope), and Roger warns against vague rationales like “the market is big.”

topics.title: Where-to-play includes value chain choices
topics.summary: Roger expands where-to-play to include vertical stage/value chain positioning, using Four Seasons’ asset-light shift and app developers’ dependence on Apple’s distribution as examples.

topics.title: How to win: low cost vs differentiation tradeoffs
topics.summary: Roger outlines how-to-win hypotheses (cheaper, easier, more integrated into workflow) and pushes back on the idea that low-cost is inherently worse, noting it often requires dominant scale.

topics.title: Capabilities: making the how-to-win real
topics.summary: They begin mapping how-to-win claims into concrete capabilities (e.g., learning curves, superior support/experience), emphasizing capabilities must operationalize the customer-facing advantage.
